## <i class="fa-solid fa-store"></i> The Challenge

A **200+ store grocery retailer** across three countries was using uniform pricing everywhere.

::: {.incremental}
- <i class="fa-solid fa-arrow-down"></i> Underpricing in affluent urban areas
- <i class="fa-solid fa-arrow-up"></i> Losing volume to discounters in price-sensitive regions
- <i class="fa-solid fa-circle-xmark"></i> Previous attempts based on gut feel failed
:::

---

## <i class="fa-solid fa-lightbulb"></i> The Approach

Built a **zone-based pricing model** using 18 months of transaction data across ~4,000 SKUs.

::: {.incremental}
- <i class="fa-solid fa-layer-group"></i> **Store clustering:** 5 pricing zones by competition, basket size, demographics
- <i class="fa-solid fa-chart-line"></i> **Category elasticity:** Separated "known value items" from margin categories
- <i class="fa-solid fa-shield-halved"></i> **Guardrails:** Maximum price differentials to avoid backlash
- <i class="fa-solid fa-rocket"></i> **Phased rollout:** 3 test zones, 200 SKUs first
:::

---

## <i class="fa-solid fa-key"></i> Key Insight

> Most retailers think "regional pricing" means charging more in rich areas.

The real opportunity is **surgical**: raise prices on items customers don't compare, stay sharp on the items they do.

::: {.highlight-box style="margin-top: 1em;"}
<i class="fa-solid fa-bullseye"></i> The zone structure matters less than understanding which products drive price perception.
:::
